item.title: First blog post
item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100
item.content:encoded: This is your very first post. Click the Edit link to modify or delete it, or start a new post. If you like, use this post to tell readers why you started this blog and what you plan to do with it.

item.title: Thoughts on "What Is User Experience Design?"
item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100

item.title: Thoughts on "What Is Design?"
item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100
item.content:encoded: This is a response to this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cOx_Zx95hxM.   This video is a talk from designer Bill Moggridge. Unlike "What Is User Experience Design?", this talk focuses on design in the more general sense, covering the field as a whole, rather than focusing only on Web design. One case study given in the talk that interested me was that of the successful i-mode cellular service from the 1990s. It shows a feature of the service — drink purchase using the Internet — that Moggridge points out is poorly designed. The problem with the service is that it is very slow, and most customers aren't interested in waiting for it. Moggridge observes that many poor designs are connected to technology. Even so, the capabilities of technology systems are so compelling that users are willing to tolerate some bad design in order to take advantage of the substantial abilities of the technologies.

item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100

item.title: Article Responses: 14 Sept. 2017
item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100
item.content:encoded: "Metrics Versus Experience" This article discusses how to be effective at making metrics-driven choices for Web-driven products, and points out that being user-focused and metrics-driven are not necessarily incompatible. There are a few points in it I especially like. One of these is the idea of focusing on retention metrics rather than conversion metrics. The article uses a "funnel" as a metaphor for user conversion and retention, which I think highlights a problem I have with a lot of Web-driven products, namely that they seem to optimize for the first part of the funnel (getting the potential user interested in the product, cultivating brand awareness, etc.) and neglect the other parts of the process (ease of onboarding, and product value / "reason" for retention). This has the consequence that I often am interested in Web services on the basis of the "buzz" surrounding them (in other words, I make it into the top of the funnel), but get tossed aside almost immediately because the services didn't optimize the experience for those later parts of the funnel. "How Google Improves User Experience with the HEART Framework" This article, following up on the previous one, discusses Google's specific strategy for Web-driven product choices, using a combination of metrics, user testing, and user feedback. I'd like to quarrel with this one, though: while the overall strategy is good, neglecting the principles described in "Metrics Versus Experience" leaves me frustrated. Specifically, the article presents the modal dialog shown in the picture at the right as "an easy, non-intrusive way to entice users to download and start using the better product experience". While that works in some cases, there are two major problems with it. First, it is obnoxious and reduces the current user experience, even though the user could probably guess there was an app without getting nagged about it. Second, individual apps often don't improve experience: often as not, they're just slow and annoying. "Reducing Cognitive Overload" This article provides ways to create user experiences that help the user be able to work with complex products. A failing in this zone is what led to the "Discord" Web communication app confusing me when I tried to use it — it simply was too visually cluttered to be practical to use. "User Memory Design" This article presents strategies for creating memorable user experiences for the user. "The UX Design Success Ladder" This article presents a similar philosophy to Donald Norman's of optimizing for both functionality and aesthetic sensibilities, and presents their coexistence as a recipe for a successful product.

item.title: Article response: "Reducing Cognitive Overload"
item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100
item.content:encoded: This post is a response to this article (IA).   This article provides ways to create user experiences that help the user be able to work with complex products. A failing in this zone is what led to the “Discord” Web communication app confusing me when I tried to use it — it simply was too visually cluttered to be practical to use. There are a number of elements of design that the article suggests contribute to cognitive overload. One of the points that really struck a chord with me is the idea of simplicity not necessarily directly corresponding to the ease of use. The article gives [caption id="attachment_159" align="alignright" width="300"] Article's example of an excessively simplified design that leads to cognitive overload (source [IA])[/caption]the screen shot to the right as an example of a user interface that, despite being simple, clean, and elegant, creates extreme cognitive overload for any user uninitiated into the arcane rites of its use. A reason this specifically resonates with me is my experiences with some similarly confusing computer user interfaces, most significantly apps created for the GNOME 3 desktop environment. For example, the Disks app, [caption id="attachment_178" align="alignnone" width="300"] Disks from GNOME 3 (source [IA])[/caption]shown to the left, while being simple, suffers from the same "mystery meat navigation" problem that afflicts the example shown in the article. While it is probably less intimidating to users who are entirely unfamiliar with computers, its tendency to break tradition from traditional computing metaphors makes it truly infuriating to use when one has familiarity with existing software, and the conventional meanings of icons. For instance, while the ⏹️︎ button, which looks like a "Stop" button from a cassette player, is logical in its meaning (it means "unmount"), it is confusing because it doesn't follow the established convention for icons representing "unmount", which is to use ⏏︎ (an "eject" symbol), used by the other major GUIs (KDE, macOS, and Windows). One reason for doing this is that when a partition is unmounted, it remains available in the interface, with the button changing to ▶︎ (a "play" symbol), but this is not immediately obvious. A better solution would be to use a text label reading "Unmount" and changing to "Mount", rather than a non-obvious icon. (Adding to the problem, the GNOME 3 Human Interface Guidelines suggest (IA) "[using] configuration options sparingly", an approach which has been taken to an unnecessary extreme — if the Guidelines' exhortation to "Use progressive disclosure" were applied, configuration options would not place any significant burden on the software's users.) Compare [caption id="attachment_220" align="alignright" width="300"] Partition management in macOS (source [IA])[/caption]the equivalent tool in an earlier version of macOS, which manages to be readable and fairly obvious in its operation, while being more visually elegant than the GNOME 3 version (although that last is rather subjective). (More recent versions of macOS have brought the interface progressively closer to the painful GNOME 3 version, which is why an older version is shown here.) Similarly, [caption id="attachment_237" align="alignleft" width="300"] KDE Partition Manager (source [IA])[/caption]the KDE Partition Manager is also quite clear in its operation, although personally I would prefer something between the KDE and macOS strategies. In summary, poorly executed simplification can lead to disorienting user interfaces that lead to cognitive overload for the user.

item.title: Customer Persona #1
item.dc:creator: elliotchandlernmd100
item.content:encoded:
Jody is a 46-year-old power company electrician, living in upstate New York. They get about 45 inches of snow each winter, in six to ten storms in a typical year. Because Jody needs to go to job sites when there are power outages — typically during storms — they often have to leave their driveway when it is snowing. Because of this, having an on-demand plow service app is critical to their business, so they can get out of their driveway. Jody makes about $30,000 per year, and has a 13 year old Scion xB SUV as their vehicle. Because the vehicle isn't very good in the snow, and is unable to accommodate a plow, Jody can't plow their own driveway.
Jody has a smart phone, so they can use a Web interface for making snow plowing requests. Jody needs an app that is simple and easy to read, because they have a hard time using software that is low-contrast, small, or otherwise hard to see, due to failing eyesight.
